abstract.para: This &standard; specifies methods to create and validate cryptographic signatures for XDI statements, subgraphs and protocol messages.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: Signatures for XDI can be applied to individual statements (triples), subgraphs and XDI protocol messages. XDI Security Mechanisms requires that XDI messages should incorporate methods to authenticate message originators, as well as methods to ensure message integrity. XDI Signatures provides one such method.

listitem.para: A graph must be able to describe specific charateristics of cryptograph material netadata.
A graph subject must be able to sign specific subgraphs. (e.g. (=example/#friend)).
A graph subject signs a specific triple found in her graph (e.g. =example<#email>&/&/"me@example.com").
A third party creates a signature over a subgraph (or single triple) to place in another entities graph (e.g. =example<#email><#work>&/&/"person@example.org" signed by @example).
Determine what is (and is not) signed in a specific graph by direct analysis of the signature triple.
Ability to validate a signature made by the graph subject or a third party
it must be possible to encrypt literals in the graph
it must be possible to encrypt a single statement in the graph
it must be possible to encrypt sub graphs in the graph
methods must be provided to address statements and sub graphs that are encrypted
it must be possible to signal when encrypted data must be stored in its' encrypted form (or not)

section.title: Usage
section.para: recommends that XDI messages should incorporate mechanisms for confidentiality, integrity and authenticity. This specification defines the manner in which cryptograph material, including certain metadata, can be included in a graph. It also defines methods for establishing signatures for XDI messages, the syntax for expressing these signatures as a sequence of triples suitable for storage in a graph. Lastly, it specifies methods for encrypting literals, triples, subgraphs and whole messages.
Since both encryption and signatures require cryptographic key material (semetric or asymetric), certain characteristics of the key material must be described. This metadata is defined in .

XDI Signatures consist of several characteristics: Algorythm information, Hashing information, and The signature itself. Processing instructions for the creation and validation of XDI signatures are provided in section .

There are several applications for XDI signatures. For XDI messages, they may be used to fufill the requirements in for message integrity and authenticity. For graph representations, signatures can indicate that the signer is asserting specific statements in the graph (for example, the graph subject is asserting a list of friends addressed by the inner root (=example/#friend) ). Signatures can also be placed in a third parties graph, indicating that the signer is asserting one or more statements about the graph subject (e.g. a subject's emlployer asserts the work email address of the subject).

The encryption mechanisms defined in this document are ssufficient to fullfill the confidentiality requirements defined in . The mecahnics of encrypting information in the graph, as well as the neccesary encryption metadata are defined in

section.title: XDI Signatures
section.para: Notes:
signatures that require SHA-256 or greater hashing, and allows for HMAC , RSA and ECDSA algorithms. In the future, additional hashing and encryption algorithms may be added.

Signatures over sub-graphs are established in a manner such that the signature may be included in the graph. This includes signatures over XDI Messages defined in . The signature covers the entire XDI subgraph rooted in that context node at that point in time. Signature may be made with a signing key rooted in the same graph as the graph from which the signature and signed content was obtained, or the signing key may be located in a different graph altogether.
Recipients of signed XDI messages SHOULD validate all signatures present in the response.

section.title: Canonical Representation
section.para: Signing XDI statements and messages involves first normalizing to the XDI Flat Serialization as defined in , and afterwards, incorporation of a Signature Block in a manner not disruptive to validators.

XDI Flat Serialization is the only serialization format used for signature creation and validation. Implementations that choose to transfer XDI messages in another serialization format MUST serialize the message in XDI Flat Serialization prior to attempting validation.

section.title: Link Contract Considerations for Signatures
section.para: Signature authors, may need to establish a specific Link Contract associated with the signature, especially when the signature is placed in a remote graph from the signed XDI subgraph or XDI Statement. Signatures need not be publicly available, but SHOULD be made available to anticipated relying parties.
